title: Wether Fell Walk Route

images.title: Chris Gunns / Alongside Roman road near Bainbridge
images.caption: Alongside Roman road near Bainbridge. This was the route taken by the Richmond to Lancaster Turnpike between 1751 and 1795, before the turnpike was diverted through Hawes, and then over Widdale to the Ribble Valley.

images.title: Trix71 / Shakes holes on wether fell
images.caption: Shakes holes on Wether Fell. The fell is popular for hang gliding and paragliding in good weather.

images.title: Roman Road by Chris McAuley, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Roman Road

images.title: On Drumaldrace by David Brown, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: On Drumaldrace, the high point of the fell. Several cairns are also to be found on the slopes of Wether Fell, some which date back as far as the Bronze Age

images.title: Bridleway which circles Wether Fell by Roger Templeman, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Bridleway which circles Wether Fell. The geology of the fell is mostly limestone with some small outcrops of millstone grit.

images.title: The Track from Yorburgh to Burtersett by Peter Wood, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The Track from Yorburgh to Burtersett

images.title: Les Hull / Bridleway below Wether Hill
images.caption: Bridleway below Wether Hill

images.title: brian alderman / The road to Semer Water and Countersett in winter.
images.caption: The road to Semer Water and Countersett in winter. Some early morning walkers set out along the Semer Water Road with their dog in bright sunshine after overnight snowfall.

description: This walk takes you up to Wether Fell and Drumaldrace Hill in the Yorkshire Dales National Park. The route starts and finishes in Bainbridge but you could also start from the village of Burtersett as the route passes through the settlement. From Bainbridge you can follow the Cam High Road all the way to the fell. The old Roman Road will take you south west across Bainbridge High Pasture, passing Horton Gill Force Waterfall on the way. At Wether Fell there is a circular bridle track running around the fell to Drumaldrace and Wether Fell Side. You'll reach a high point of 614 metres (2,014 ft) with wonderful views over the area.
